aToolTip: Review of the overall strategies and drivers of an organization’s research data program.
bToolTip: The tactical management positioning in an organization for effective research data management throughout the research data lifecycle.
cToolTip: The generation of raw research data, both experimentally and computationally, within an organization, and the collection or acquisition of research data produced outside of an organization.
dToolTip: The actions performed on generated or externally acquired research data to yield processed research data, typically using software, from which observations and conclusions can be made.
eToolTip: How raw and processed research data are disseminated, used, and reused within an organization and any constraints or encouragements to use/reuse. It also includes the dissemination, use, and reuse of raw and processed research data outside of an organization.
fToolTip: The end-of-use and end-of-life provisions for research data in an organization and includes records management, archiving, and safe disposal.

text: Social license for use and reuse
Incentives and impact for sharing and reuse
Workforce preparedness in new and advanced technologies
HR’s supporting role in workforce development and training
Engagement across knowledge domains and sectors
Centralized inventory of services, groups, and resources
Purpose/intent of research study and context of anticipated data use
Specification of data objects, metadata, analysis tools, and workflows throughout the lifecycle
Linkage of DMPs to administrative records
Data organization in, e.g., a database and a repository, to facilitate future access
Measurements, including images, audio recordings, and photos/videos
Organizational support for making data more FAIR
Identification of methods/guidelines vis-à-vis FAIR principles
Methods to capture and store data/metadata
Models that connect infrastructure to data processes and workflow
Sustainability of data vis-à-vis obsolete infrastructure
Criteria, i.e., general vs. domain-specific standards
Metrics for tracking use and impact measures, including reuse
Methods to share and reuse data/metadata
Allocation of credit to project team members
Promotion of data to communities of interest
Requests for additional data from community
Identification of responsible parties for access
Ease of maintenance and implementation of records
Measurements, including images, audio recordings, photos/videos
Infrastructure to assure the greatest data integrity
Aggregation of data evaluated by experts
Guidelines/methodologies for each aspect: F, A, I, R
Standards development organizations vs. community consensus

aToolTip:
The policies, procedures, and processes pertaining to authority, control,
and shared decision-making (planning, monitoring, and enforcement) over the management of data assets
The policies, procedures, and processes to manage and monitor an organization’s regulatory [and] legal responsibilities and risks pertaining to data.
yToolTip: Considerations for E.2

aToolTip: The collective beliefs and behaviors of the people in an organization concerning the value and management of research data. Practices designed to recognize the advantages and accomplishments of sharing data.
yToolTip: Considerations for E.3

aToolTip: Training to provide staff with the necessary skills and expertise for data-related activities and RDM. Includes leadership support and formal and informal training.
The distribution and longevity of funding to attain and maintain robust research data programs and RDM infrastructure.
Outreach and interactions among organizations or individuals with shared goals or interests concerning research data activities or RDM
yToolTip: Considerations for E.6

aToolTip: A complete, fully documented step-by-step history of a data asset in an organization, i.e., who has possession of a data asset, at what time, and for what purpose, at all times throughout the lifecycle of the data asset.
Factors to consider in estimating or assessing the costs associated with all research data and RDM activities over the data lifecycle.
The process of organizing and specifying objectives and activities throughout the research data lifecycle.
yToolTip: Considerations for P.3

aToolTip: An entity that, together with associated Representative Information (i.e., metadata), is produced or used in a research study
Findability, Accessibility, Interoperability, Reuse: a set of guiding principles to support the reusability of data that are beneficial to all scholarly digital research objects.
Factors to take into account prior to conducting a research study

The fundamental structure of an organization's research data management (RDM) system embodied in its components, their relationships to each other and to the environment, and the principles guiding its design and evolution. Includes, for example, the underlying storage technologies, networking, hardware, system interfaces, authentication mechanisms, data brokers, monitoring platforms, semantic interoperability tools, long-term preservation services, and HPC.
The physical and non-physical functional components that collectively form a foundation for conducting research and RDM
yToolTip: Considerations for P.8

aToolTip: Documents, including codes, specifications, recommended practices, classifications, test methods and guides, that describe how data should be stored or exchanged for the consistent collection and interoperability of that data across different systems, sources, and users.
Evaluation of the success of a research project against expectations set before the project has started
Engagement and interactions among groups and Individual working in similar research areas

text: Access Control Associated with Data Sensitivity
aToolTip: Methods and requirements to limit the individuals and groups permitted to view or use protected data.
Classifications or categories of data, each with unique collection, generation, and storage challenges
Where and from which processes data originates
Collection of information through active intervention by the researcher to induce and measure changes or to create differences when a variable is altered
Production of information resulting from executing a computer model or simulation
Non-ordinal and focusing on qualities or characteristics
Obtained from a source outside of the researchers and which was not originally collected for the current research project
Collected and processed in a standardized way with rigorous methodology to serve as a standard
Technical specifications for encoding metadata for machine processing and exchange
Programs that enable the collection and procurement of data
